DataElement.preferredName: Prior Therapy Agent Route of Administration Type Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The route of administration of the medication/treatment that was administered before protocol therapy.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Concomitant Medication Domain Prior Therapy Agent Route of Administration
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to concomitant medication administration._An indicator that a person has been previously treated for the same condition or with the same therapy._An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect._Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to concomitant medication administration.

Concepts.definition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to concomitant medication administration.

Property.preferredName: Prior Therapy Agent Route of Administration
Property.preferredDefinition: An indicator that a person has been previously treated for the same condition or with the same therapy.:An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect.:Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.

Concepts.definition: Prior action or administration of therapeutic agents that produced an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.
An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect.

Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Released. AK 2020-6-10; Created for CDSIC aligned NCI Standard CRFs. ghd

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An enumerated set of text codes and names to represent an access route for the administration of agents, evaluation of vital signs, etc.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration to or by way of the ear.

Concepts.definition: Administration of the drug to or by way of the ear. The drug action is mostly topical/local.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Endotracheal drug administration involves the introduction of the agent directly through the endotracheal tube in an intubated patient. Generally this route is considered as a last resort for drug administration, and provides a fast, effective means of drug delivery in a patient who requires immediate medication. Plasma levels obtained via endotracheal administration are considerably less than those obtained with an equal dosage administered intravenously or intraosseously. Endotracheal administration must be followed by hyper-insufflation of the lungs to promote optimal drug absorption.

Concepts.definition: Endotracheal drug administration involves the introduction of the agent directly through the endotracheal tube in an intubated patient. Generally this route is considered as a last resort for drug administration, and provides a fast, effective means of drug delivery in a patient who requires immediate medication. Plasma levels obtained via endotracheal administration are considerably less than those obtained with an equal dosage administered intravenously or intraosseously. Endotracheal administration must be followed by hyper-insufflation of the lungs to promote optimal drug absorption.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration to or in the interstices of a tissue.

Concepts.definition: Drug administration to or in the interstices of a tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The route of drug administration is unknown.

Concepts.definition: The route of drug administration is unknown.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/11/23 Edited so definition of VM is visible per cleanup activities cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Within the skin.

Concepts.definition: Within the skin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration of a drug directly into circulation via a vein or veins over a time duration of less than or equal to 30 minutes. Method results in 100% bioavailability of the agent due to an absence of the absorption phase. FDA CDER (HL7) numeric code: 0138

Concepts.definition: A volume of drug intended to be administered into a vein at a relatively fast rate. The volume of drug and the rate of administration are specified.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Introduction of a drug directly into venous circulation over the time duration of more than 30 minutes but less than 24 hours. Method results in 100% bioavailability of the agent due to an absence of the absorption phase and provides a precise and continuous mode of drug therapy, especially for drugs with a narrow therapeutic index. To achieve the steady state quickly, the loading dose is used. Intravenously administered drug is diluted in the pooled venous blood and pumped through lungs before entering systematic circulation (lung first-pass effect). The target organ receives only the fraction of drug corresponding to the fraction of received arterial blood.

Concepts.definition: Introduction of a drug directly into venous circulation over the time duration of more than 30 minutes but less than 24 hours. Method results in 100% bioavailability of the agent due to an absence of the absorption phase and provides a precise and continuous mode of drug therapy, especially for drugs with a narrow therapeutic index. To achieve the steady state quickly, the loading dose is used. Intravenously administered drug is diluted in the pooled venous blood and pumped through lungs before entering systematic circulation (lung first-pass effect). The target organ receives only the fraction of drug corresponding to the fraction of received arterial blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A route of administration of a fluid drug form into a vein or veins, over a time duration of equal to or more than 24 hours. Method allows to maintain steady state plasma/serum medication levels, a smaller total daily dose of drug to achieve the same pharmacodynamic endpoint in comparison with intermittent or bolus infusion, and may result in lower toxicity. The method has a positive impact on health-care costs.

Concepts.definition: A route of administration of a fluid drug form into a vein or veins, over a time duration of equal to or more than 24 hours. Method allows to maintain steady state plasma/serum medication levels, a smaller total daily dose of drug to achieve the same pharmacodynamic endpoint in comparison with intermittent or bolus infusion, and may result in lower toxicity. The method has a positive impact on health-care costs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Within an artery (blood vessel that carries blood from the heart to tissues and organs in the body).

Concepts.definition: Within an artery (blood vessel that carries blood from the heart to tissues and organs in the body).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Beneath the skin.

Concepts.definition: Beneath the skin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration within the cerebrospinal fluid at any level of the cerebrospinal axis, including injection into the cerebral ventricles.

Concepts.definition: Administration of drugs directly into spinal subarachnoid space in the cerebrospinal fluid, at any level of the cerebrospinal axis, including injection into the cerebral ventricles, in order to bypass the blood-brain barrier and achieve local, rapid effects on the meninges or cerebrospinal axis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (IN-tra-per-ih-toe-NEE-al) IP.  Within the peritoneal cavity (the area that contains the abdominal organs).

Concepts.definition: Relating to the peritoneal cavity as the intended site of administration.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (in-tra-hep-AT-ik) Within the liver.

Concepts.definition: Within the liver.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration of a fluid form of the drug via a blood vessel into the liver over the sustained period of time.

Concepts.definition: Administration of a fluid form of the drug via a blood vessel into the liver over the sustained period of time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The introduction of a substance to the mouth or into the gastrointestinal tract by the way of the mouth, usually for systemic action. It is the most common, convenient, and usually the safest and least expensive route of drug administration, but it uses the most complicated pathway to the tissues and bioavailability varies. The disadvantages of method are hepatic first pass metabolism and enzymatic degradation of the drug within the gastrointestinal tract. This prohibits oral administration of certain classes of drugs especially peptides and proteins.

Concepts.definition: The introduction of a substance to the mouth or into the gastrointestinal tract by the way of the mouth, usually for systemic action. It is the most common, convenient, and usually the safest and least expensive route of drug administration, but it uses the most complicated pathway to the tissues and bioavailability varies. The disadvantages of method are hepatic first pass metabolism and enzymatic degradation of the drug within the gastrointestinal tract. This prohibits oral administration of certain classes of drugs especially peptides and proteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The area of the body exposed to radiation during radiation therapy.

Concepts.definition: The area of the body exposed to radiation during radiation therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Related to the rectum

Concepts.definition: Of or pertaining to the rectum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Through the skin.

Concepts.definition: Referring to the application of medication through the skin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Beneath the tongue.

Concepts.definition: Beneath the tongue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Intramuscular.  Within or into muscle.

Concepts.definition: Within or into muscle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration to the nose; administered by way of the nose.

Concepts.definition: In reference to the nose.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration of a liquid substance to the oral mucosa by swishing the drug inside the mouth for a certain amount of time then spiting it out. The drug action is mostly topical/local.

Concepts.longName: Swish and Spit Route of Administration
Concepts.definition: Administration of a liquid substance to the oral mucosa by swishing the drug inside the mouth for a certain amount of time then spiting it out. The drug action is mostly topical/local.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration of a liquid substance to the oral mucosa by swishing the drug inside the mouth for a certain amount of time then allowed to be swallowed. The drug action is both topical and systemic

Concepts.longName: Swish and Swallow Route of Administration
Concepts.definition: Administration of a liquid substance to the oral mucosa by swishing the drug inside the mouth for a certain amount of time then allowed to be swallowed. The drug action is both topical and systemic

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On the surface of the body.

Concepts.definition: On the surface of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration through the nose and into the stomach, usually by means of a tube.

Concepts.definition: Administration of a drug through the nose and into the stomach, usually by means of a tube.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Access within the respiratory tract by inhaling orally or nasally for a systemic or local effect.

Concepts.definition: A disorder characterized by inhalation of solids or liquids into the lungs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Drug administration through a gastric fistula or a surgically created artificial opening into the stomach through the abdominal wall with insertion of a tube.

Concepts.definition: Drug administration through a gastric fistula or a surgically created artificial opening into the stomach through the abdominal wall with insertion of a tube.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Used to refer to every member of a group of people or things, considered individually.: The organ of sight or vision.: Administration of a drug to the external eye.

Concepts.definition: Used to refer to every member of a group of people or things, considered individually.
The organ of sight or vision.
Administration of a drug to the external surfaces of the eye.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.: The organ of sight or vision.: Administration of a drug to the external eye.

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
The organ of sight or vision.
Administration of a drug to the external surfaces of the eye.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Right; being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.: The organ of sight or vision.: Administration of a drug to the external eye.

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
The organ of sight or vision.
Administration of a drug to the external surfaces of the eye.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Within a tumor.

Concepts.definition: Within a tumor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Relating to the vagina or to any sheath.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to the vagina.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration of a substance to the mucosa; often resulting in systemic action due to absorption.

Concepts.definition: Administration of a substance to the mucosa; often resulting in systemic action due to absorption.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration within a ventricle.

Concepts.definition: Administration of a drug directly into a cerebral ventricle, commonly using a reservoir. This allows a more even distribution of drug through the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and is particularly useful in the treatment of certain types of cancers.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Within the bladder.

Concepts.definition: Within the bladder.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Oral and Intravenous Route of Administration

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Oral and Intravenous Route of Administration
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The introduction of a substance to the mouth or into the gastrointestinal tract by the way of the mouth, usually for systemic action. It is the most common, convenient, and usually the safest and least expensive route of drug administration, but it uses the most complicated pathway to the tissues and bioavailability varies. The disadvantages of method are hepatic first pass metabolism and enzymatic degradation of the drug within the gastrointestinal tract. This prohibits oral administration of certain classes of drugs especially peptides and proteins.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: Administration within or into a vein or veins.: The course by which a substance was administered in order to reach the site of action in the body.

Concepts.definition: The introduction of a substance to the mouth or into the gastrointestinal tract by the way of the mouth, usually for systemic action. It is the most common, convenient, and usually the safest and least expensive route of drug administration, but it uses the most complicated pathway to the tissues and bioavailability varies. The disadvantages of method are hepatic first pass metabolism and enzymatic degradation of the drug within the gastrointestinal tract. This prohibits oral administration of certain classes of drugs especially peptides and proteins.
An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.

Administration of a drug within or into a vein or veins. Introduction of the drug directly into venous circulation results in 100% bioavailability due to an absence of the absorption phase, provides a precise and continuous mode of drug therapy, especially for drugs with a narrow therapeutic index.

Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration of a drug directly into the urethra.

Concepts.definition: Administration of a drug directly into the urethra.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration within the uterus.

Concepts.definition: The administration of a drug within the uterus.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Corpora Cavernosa Intracavernous Route of Administration

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Corpora Cavernosa Intracavernous Route of Administration
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of two chambers along the shaft of the penis containing spongy erectile tissue, which, combined with the Corpus Spongiosum, fill with blood to create a penile erection.: Administration of a drug within a pathologic cavity.

Concepts.definition: One of two chambers along the shaft of the penis containing spongy erectile tissue, which, combined with the Corpus Spongiosum, fill with blood to create a penile erection.
Administration of a drug within a pathologic cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration of a drug within a pathologic cavity.

Concepts.definition: Administration of a drug within a pathologic cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Administration within a joint.

Concepts.definition: Administration of the drug within a joint.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Use of a syringe and needle to push fluids or drugs into the body; often called a "shot."

Concepts.definition: Administration of a drug into a location within the body; this can be achieved either through an established access or via a needle.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The course by which a substance was administered in order to reach the site of action in the body.:Text; the words of something written.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: Designation of the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product is intended to be introduced. In some cases a medicinal product can be intended for more than one route and/or method of administration.
The words of something written.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
